Issues.Title: Issue in the form size while setting Dpi
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 

   3.1 Preview 1

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 

   Yes

**Problem description:**

I have created the winforms project with DataGridView. I have enabled the dpi settings to the application. I have found some issues while running the application. 

### Issue 1:

After setting the AutoScaleDimensions as below, the NetCore form size greater than the framework. Please refer the below Image

 Code Snippet

`this.AutoScaleDimensions = new System.Drawing.SizeF(6F, 13F);`

Images

NetFramework :

![NetFrameWorkImage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63052528/107309855-3f60db80-6ab1-11eb-88cf-c6ea13c74140.png)

NetCore :

![NetCoreImage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63052528/107310009-88189480-6ab1-11eb-8c5f-95006a011227.png)

Note : This issue occurs only when setting autoscaledimensions.

Issue 2:

While i launch the application in the 150dpi, the application moves out of screen area. Please refer the below image. And this issue occurs in the both NetFramework and Netcore.

Image:

NetCore Image:

![150% NetCore](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63052528/107310271-1c82f700-6ab2-11eb-82de-17383a883676.png)

NetFrameWork Image

![150% NetFrameWork](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63052528/107310367-463c1e00-6ab2-11eb-9d9d-39c839cb42dd.png)

Note : I'm running this application in the resolution 1366 X 768 and in the Dell laptop.

**Expected behavior:**

Issue 1: I'm expecting for both the NetFramework and NetCore the form size should be same.

Issue 2 : I'm  expecting this form should not moves out of the screen area. 

**Minimal repro:**

Issue 1:

Run the NetCore and NetFramework2017 applications in the 100% dpi.
you can able to replicate the issue.

Issue 2:

Run the NetCore application in the 150% dpi.
 
Please find the below Sample.

[Sample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5948519/Sample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Issue in the form size while setting Dpi " (#4543)

Issues.Title: Correctly rethrow exceptions
Issues.Body:
Resolves #4536

<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->




## Proposed changes

`Control.Invoke` incorrectly rethrown exception thrown from original invoked methods, thus losing the original stack, and the new exception appeared as though if began at `Control.MarshaledInvoke` method.

Use `ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw` to preserve the original stack trace.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

Issues.Title: Synchronous Control.Invoke overwrites call stack by exception thrown by the UI Thread
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
All versions

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Problem description:**

[Control.Invoke rethrows](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/127afbcc039b7462ca46411504d5a91c5dc1d167/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Control.cs#L6829) any exception thrown from the original method, throwing away the original stack from the UI thread and causing the exception to appear as if began at Control.MarshaledInvoke:

```
System.Windows.Forms.ni!System.Windows.Forms.Control.MarshaledInvoke in f:\dd\ndp\fx\src\winforms\Managed\System\WinForms\Control.csControl.cs:line 7783
at System.Windows.Forms.ni!System.Windows.Forms.Control.Invoke in f:\dd\ndp\fx\src\winforms\Managed\System\WinForms\Control.csControl.cs:line 7373
at SomeCustomMethodThatControlInvokes
at mscorlib.ni!System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart_Context in f:\dd\ndp\clr\src\BCL\system\threading\thread.csthread.cs:line 74
at mscorlib.ni!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal in f:\dd\ndp\clr\src\BCL\system\threading\executioncontext.csexecutioncontext.cs:line 980
at mscorlib.ni!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run in f:\dd\ndp\clr\src\BCL\system\threading\executioncontext.csexecutioncontext.cs:line 928
at mscorlib.ni!System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run in f:\dd\ndp\clr\src\BCL\system\threading\executioncontext.csexecutioncontext.cs:line 917
at mscorlib.ni!System.Threading.ThreadHelper.ThreadStart in f:\dd\ndp\clr\src\BCL\system\threading\thread.csthread.cs:line 111
```
This makes it very difficult to see the original problem in crash dumps, and has made triaging Watsons in Visual Studio much harder.

Please use [ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw(ex)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.runtime.exceptionservices.exceptiondispatchinfo.throw?view=net-5.0#System_Runtime_ExceptionServices_ExceptionDispatchInfo_Throw_System_Exception_) so that original call stack is maintained.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Synchronous Control.Invoke overwrites call stack by exception thrown by the UI Thread" (#4536)

Issues.Title: Fixing the problem with forced creation of a handle when resizing a ComboBox
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4541 


## Proposed changes
- The issue is reproduced because the resize triggers the "OnResize" event which triggers the "InvalidateEverything" where we get the "Handle" property. As a fix, added "IsHandleCreated" check, before calling the "InvalidateEverything" method.
- Added unit tests


## Customer Impact
- No 

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk
- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- Unit tests

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19041.388]
- .NET Core SDK 5.0.200-preview.20614.14


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4542)

Issues.Title: Resizing the ComboBox with "Simple" dropDownStyle forcibly creates a handle
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**
- 5.0.200-preview.20614.14

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:**
- Yes

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create application with ComboBox.
2. Set "Simple" drop down style.
3. Set custom size.

For example:
```
ComboBox comboBox = new ComboBox();
comboBox.DropDownStyle = ComboBoxStyle.DropDown;
comboBox.Size = new System.Drawing.Size(50, 50);
bool isHandleCreated = comboBox.IsHandleCreated;
```

**Expected behavior:**
Handle is not created

**Actual behavior**
Handle is created.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Resizing the ComboBox with "Simple" dropDownStyle forcibly creates a handle" (#4541)

Issues.Title: Adding support for text pattern to ComboBox
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4409
## Proposed changes
- Added ComboBoxUiaTextProvider class to support TextPattern. Its logic is based on the TextBoxBaseUiaTextProvider, but we use the native control handle, which is responsible for editing
- Added unit tests

Issues.Title: Accessibility: The focus dotline rectangle for Button cannot be visible obviously when using keyboard focus it
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
6.0.100-preview1.1.21107.2

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No
* More Info: 
1. This is a regression issue, cannot repro in .Net Core 3.1 and .Net 5.0 builds
2. This issue cannot repro using mouse click buttons

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core app
2. Add several buttons to form designer
3. Build and run app
4. Use Tab keyboard to focus on buttons, observe

**Actual behavior:**
The focus dotline rectangle for Button cannot be visible obviously, see following screenshot and GIF for 6.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/107194261-c61ea580-6a2a-11eb-9743-e5396839dc9c.png)
![keyboard_Button](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/107194327-dc2c6600-6a2a-11eb-956f-5f4c1509f913.gif)

**Expected behavior:**
The focus dotline rectangle for Button is visible obviously on .Net Core 3.1 or .Net 5.0, see following screenshot and GIF for 5.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/107194297-d33b9480-6a2a-11eb-98a9-ff56af3faeb3.png)
![keyboard_Button_5 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/107194338-dfbfed00-6a2a-11eb-816d-e913a201729f.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: The focus dotline rectangle for Button cannot be visible obviously when using keyboard focus it" (#4538)

Issues.Title: Allow custom controls in StatusStrip
Issues.Body:
StatusStrip control only allows for 4 built-in child controls: StatusLabel, ProgressBar, DropDownButtom, and SplitButton.

It would be cool if you could have your own panel in there, picturebox, custom-drawn tool, or usercontrol.  Like this

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8064022/106989892-c53ef880-6738-11eb-92d5-f4f9d39f7116.png)

It seems the old StatusBar [supported this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/desktop/winforms/controls/how-to-add-panels-to-a-statusbar-control?view=netframeworkdesktop-4.8), but its not useable in .NET 5.

Is this something that can be added?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow custom controls in StatusStrip" (#4531)

Issues.Title: Question: Suggest how to port winforms
Issues.Body:
I recently found a libgdiplus here: https://github.com/CoreCompat/libgdiplus-packaging

I was curious, I understand there's no interest in supporting MacOS and Linux, but has anyone ever thought about what would be the roadmap in a what if scenario?

Such roadmap would be useful if some group of people decides to pickup on their own, taking advantage of the now open source codebase.

Edit: label is wrong.

Issues.Title: Versioning of libraries and designer
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.x

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**

We are running Visual Studio 16.9.0 Preview 3.0 which ships with some .NET 5.0.2 bits. These bits are consumed by the WinForms designer. The designer then serializes these types into .resx along with the version of the library, eg.:
```
  <assembly alias="System.Windows.Forms.Primitives" name="System.Windows.Forms.Primitives, Version=5.0.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089" />
  <data name="label_Title.Margin" type="System.Windows.Forms.Padding, System.Windows.Forms.Primitives">
    <value>0, 3, 3, 3</value>
  </data>
```

The application itself is however compiled with a fixed version of .NET framework specified in global.json file:
```
{
  "sdk": {
    "version": "5.0.100",
    "allowPrerelease": true,
    "rollForward": "latestFeature"
  }
}
```

This results in issue where the serialized types cannot be loaded at runtime and crash the app.

**Expected behavior:**

Assembly versions (as opposed to file versions!) should not change between service releases, or designer should target the same service release the application is compiled with.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Versioning of libraries and designer" (#4528)

Issues.Title: Issue in NetCore while enabling Dpi
Issues.Body: * .NET Core Version: 3.0 Preview2 * Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No, **Problem description:** I have created the project with DataGridView. I have enabled the dpi settings to my project. While launching my NetCore application in 150dpi, the DataGridView is not rendered correctly in the form. Please refer the below image Mean while i have launched 4.6 NetFramework project with same settings, i didn't faced the issue like NetCore. please refer below image. Note : Issue in the NetCore occurs only when setting anchor property to the DataGridView. **Expected behavior:** This issue not occurs in the 100dpi. Please refer the below image. This should be a expected behavior i believe. ![NetCore_100Dpi](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63052528/106877898-52fdf200-66ff-11eb-9bfb-195881d9205c.png) **Minimal repro:** Run the NetCore sample below in 150 dpi resolution. Above mentioned issue occurs. [Samples.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5929896/Samples.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Issue in NetCore while enabling Dpi" (#4527)

Issues.Title: Properly apply translation and clipping in TextRenderer
Issues.Body:
Translation and clipping should only be applied from Graphics objects when they are explicitly asked for in the TextFormatFlags.

Adds regression tests.

Fixes #4524


## Proposed changes

- Apply graphics properties only when requested
- Add regression tests

## Customer Impact

- This causes rendering to not work correctly when transforms and clipping are in play.
- This shows up in 3rd party control libraries, such as Telerik's. It can cause text to "vanish" as it isn't rendered in the clipped area.
- Workarounds are difficult, particularly when this shows up in 3rd party control libraries.

## Regression? 

- Yes

## Risk

- Very low

## Screenshots

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8184940/106831203-5bddbd80-6644-11eb-8086-ec71b09ff9ba.png)

### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8184940/106831163-48325700-6644-11eb-9cad-8e80748912a9.png)


## Test methodology

- Test Telerik provided repro
- Audit of legacy code
- Add regression tests

Issues.Title: Use local definition of disabledPackageSources
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4516

## Proposed changes

Clear the `disabledPackageSources` in `nuget.config` to prevent global settings affecting the locally setup sources. In particular it could happen that in Visual Studio UI a package source with the same key was defined but unchecked, in which case the local `nuget.config` would ignore the local definition of that source because it inherited the `disabledPackageSources` from the global settings.

This also matches what other projects like [arcade](https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/blob/8b7ec67401393a062292446cf9602c9a0b64c758/NuGet.config) are doing

## Customer Impact

Allow local builds independent of global nuget settings

## Regression? 

unknown

## Risk

none, other projects like arcarde are doing it too

### Before

local builds fail if a package source with the same key is defined but unchecked in the global Visual Studio settings

### After

local builds succeed independent of global Visual Studio settings

## Test methodology

manual testing (defining a package source with the same key and unchecking it in Visual Studio UI)

You may have to clear your local package cache first if you want to reproduce the failure cases.

Issues.Title: Local builds failing
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**
main branch

**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:**
no

**Problem description:**
Local builds fail if you have global nuget sources unchecked and they happen to have the same key as one of the sources defined in the local `nuget.config`

**Expected behavior:**
`nuget.config` in the repo should be independent from the global nuget sources

**Minimal repro:**
Add a feed with the same name as in the winforms `nuget.config` and uncheck it in the Visual Studio UI. Might require clearing the local package cache to reproduce the failure.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Local builds failing" (#4516)
